question: Concerning of the roles of ITAM and ITIM in regulating immune response, which statement is true?

options.A: ITAMs and ITIMs, negatively and positively, respectively regulate immune response.
options.B: PD-1 has ITAMs, so anti-PD-1 can activate T-cell, allowing the killing of tumor cells and serving as immune therapeutic treatment.
options.C: An TCR has 6 ITAMs on its inter membrane side.
options.D: Lck, a serine kinase family member, requires CD45.

explanation:
Contrary. ITAM (activation) can promote immune response, and ITIM (inhibition) can inhibit immune response.
(B) PD1 has ITIM, so anti-PD-1 can prevent ITIM from inhibiting T cells, promoting T cell killing of cancer cells.
(C) TCR itself does not have ITAM. The ITAMs of the TCR complex come from 6 on the ζ chain, plus 2 ITAMs on each of the two sets of CD3, totaling 10 ITAMs.
(D) Lck is a tyrosine kinase. Lck is initially in a phosphorylated (deactivated) state. When TCR contacts the antigen, CD45 dephosphorylates pTyr on Lck, activating Lck. [From Exam Archaeology Q1]

question: CAR-T and immune checkpoint blockade are two breakthroughs in recent years. Which of the statements concerning two approaches is correct?

options.A: CAR-T approach bypasses the requirement of the recognition of MHC peptide and 2 signals to activate antigen-presenting-T cell.
options.B: Immune checkpoint blockade is to block the molecules that transduce inhibiting signals in antigen presenting cells.
options.C: CAR-T and immune checkpoint blockade both work for solid tumor and leukemia efficiently.
options.D: The mechanism for anti-CTLA-4 and anti-PD-1 immune checkpoint blockade is the same; therefore, there is no increased therapeutic activity when doing combined treatment.

explanation:
(A) Correct.
(B) It does not block the antigen-presenting cells, but blocks the inhibitory signal receptors of immune cells (T cells), so that T cells are not inhibited.
(C) CAR-T is currently only effective against leukemia or other blood tumors, and has not yet been applied to solid tumor treatment.
(D) The mechanisms of action of Anti-CTLA-4 and Anti-PD-1 are not completely the same. Anti-CTLA-4 targets when T cells receive antigen presentation, blocking the CTLA-4 receptor, so that the B7 of the antigen-presenting cell binds to CD28 of the T cell, activating the T cell. Anti-CD-1 targets when T cells contact cancer cells, blocking the PD-1 receptor of the T cell, so that it will not be inhibited by the PD-L1 of the cancer cell. Using the two drugs together may enhance the effect, but it may also have more autoimmune side effects. [From Exam Archaeology Q2]

question: AMPs belong to a component of innate immune system. Which statement concerning AMPs is CORRECT?

options.A: AMPs are produced by non-immune cells in skins, lungs and guts where the host is exposed directly to the outside environment and by some innate cells.
options.B: AMPs are produced in an active form and can kill bacteria immediately.
options.C: AMPs are peptides with a hydrophobic end and a hydrophilic end, which will kill the cell wall of bacteria.
options.D: AMPs have selective killing ability toward bacteria but not host cell.

explanation:
(A) AMPs are produced by epithelial tissues and phagocytes. Such as: stratum spinosum in the skin, Paneth cells in the intestinal epithelium.
(B) AMPs are usually in an inactive state (Pro-AMP) when produced and need to be cleaved by proteases to become active after the pro-region, called proteolysis.
(C) AMPs are amphipathic peptides that can penetrate the cell membrane and form pores, not the cell wall.
(D) AMPs are not specific. When bacteria appear, Pro-AMP will be cleaved and activated, so it will not kill host cells. Another saying is that the structure of bacterial cell membranes is more likely to attract AMPs than host cells. [From Exam Archaeology Q3]

question: The complement system is crucial for the host to defend against bacterial infection. Which of the following concerning activation and function of complement is correct?

options.A: The classical pathway and lectin pathway both generate C3 convertase C4b2a. The structure of the C1r and C1s are similar to the MBL.
options.B: MBL and ficolins, which are the components of lectin pathway, are produced in the liver in response to the infection.
options.C: The complement inhibitor, such as C3b, is only produced in the host cell but no in the bacteria, which is why the complement selectively kills the microbes.
options.D: The C3b not only acts as opsonin, but is also chemo-attractive which attract leukocytes to the site of infection.

explanation:
(A) C1r and C1s are structurally similar to MASP1 and MASP2. MBL is structurally similar to C1q.
(B) Correct.
(C) C3b is not an inhibitor. Inhibitors (regulatory proteins) are CR1 and H, which are only present on normal cells.
(D) C3a and C5a can promote the movement of phagocytes to the infected and inflamed areas. [From Exam Archaeology Q4]

question: Which of the following is correct?

options.A: $\text{TNF-α}$ is a proinflammatory cytokine that acts on endothelial cells, skeleton muscle, and the heart to trigger different effects, which is the pleiotropic effect of cytokines.
options.B: IL-6 can trigger acute phase response through binding to kidney.
options.C: IFN-Is, including $\text{IFN-α}$, $\text{IFN-β}$, $\text{IFN-γ}$, induced by TLR-3 and TLR-7 signaling pathway are critical to triggering antiviral response.
options.D: LPS-induced overproduction of IL-6 during systemic bacterial infection can trigger disseminated intravascular coagulation and multiorgan failure, which is called endotoxic shock.

explanation:
(A) Correct.
(B) IL-6 triggers acute phase responses through binding to hepatocytes (liver).
(C) IFN-Is ($\text{IFN-α}$ and $\text{IFN-β}$) are primarily induced by TLR-3 and TLR-7 signaling pathways and trigger antiviral response. $\text{IFN-γ}$ (Type II IFN) is induced by TLR-4 signaling pathway triggered by the LPS of Gram-negative bacteria.
(D) Correct. [From Exam Archaeology Q5]

question: Which statement concerning TLR is correct?

options.A: TLRs are expressed on plasma membrane, endosome and cytosol, to recognize PAMPs and trigger acute responses.
options.B: Except for TLR4, all other TLRs signal through MyD88, an adaptor molecule.
options.C: TLRs are single-pass transmembrane protein with leucine-rich repeat that recognize PAMPS.
options.D: TLR3 recognizes dsRNA, which is a PAMP of the virus genome, in cytosol.

explanation:
(A) TLRs are only expressed on plasma membrane and endosome.
(B) Except for TLR3, all other TLRs signal through MyD88.
(C) Correct.
(D) TLR3 which binds dsRNA is located in endosome. [From Exam Archaeology Q6]

question: Macrophage and neutrophil are phagocytes, which of the followings is correct?

options.A: Both can produce lysozyme to dissolve LPS of the Gram-negative G (-) bacterial cell wall.
options.B: Macrophage can produce lactoferrin, which competes $\text{Fe}^\text{2+}$, which is a necessary ion for bacterial replication.
options.C: Upon bacterial infection, neutrophil can undergo NETosis to form extracellular trap (NET), in which releases its nuclear chromatin, trapping but not kill pathogens.
options.D: Neutrophils tracks down bacteria with G-protein coupled receptors that sense fMLF which is a peptide specific to bacteria.

explanation:
(A) Both produce Lysozyme which digests cell walls of some Gram-positive bacteria.
(B) Neutrophil can produce lactoferrin which competes $\text{Fe}^\text{2+}$.
(C) NETs contain elastase, myelo-peroxidase, cathepsin G and lactoferrin which degrade or block pathogens.
(D) Correct. [From Exam Archaeology Q7]

question: Clonal Selection Theory (CST) is the foundation of adaptive immunity. Which statement concerning CST is correct?

options.A: CST explains self-tolerance because self-reactive T and B lymphocytes are deleted in the bone marrow.
options.B: Based on CST, tissues can be successfully transplanted into foreign recipients when recipient's immune system is mature.
options.C: CST explains antigen specificity because each lymphocyte expresses a distinct antigen receptor, and only lymphocytes that react with a given antigen can undergo expansion.
options.D: Dr. Peter Medawar first hypothesized CST and received the Nobel Prize later.

explanation:
(A) Self-reactive T lymphocytes are deleted in the thymus.
(B) The success of tissue transplantation depends on factors beyond CST, such as histocompatibility and immune suppression.
(C) Correct.
(D) CST was first proposed by Dr. Macfarlane Burnet (who later jointly received the Nobel Prize with Dr. Peter Medawar for the discovery of acquired immunological tolerance). [From Exam Archaeology Q8]

question: Presentation of pre-B receptor is an important checkpoint in B cell development. Which statement concerning signal from pre-B receptor is CORRECT?

options.A: Will inhibit light chain gene rearrangement.
options.B: Will promote heavy chain gene rearrangement.
options.C: Will promote surrogate light gene rearrangement.
options.D: Will enhance pre-B cell proliferation.

explanation:
(A) Should be PROMOTE light chain gene rearrangement.
(B) Should be STOP heavy chain gene rearrangement.
(C) The surrogate light chain (SLC) is only used for stabilization and is not related to gene rearrangement.
(D) Correct, pre-B cell signals will promote the maturation and differentiation of downstream B cells. (See B10 Notes vol.1, p.74, Fig. 8.5) [From Exam Archaeology Q9]

question: The vaccination method invented by Dr. Jenner and the variolation method by Chinese doctor both induce immunity against smallpox. Which is correct?

options.A: The reason vaccination works is because the virus that cause cowpox is the same as smallpox.
options.B: Theoretically, the efficiency of the immunity cause by variolation is better than vaccination.
options.C: Because of the invention of vaccination, smallpox was eradicated within 50 years after its invention.
options.D: The side effect of variolation could have been avoided if the inoculation had been via the subcutaneous route like vaccination instead of nasal route.

explanation:
(A) It's not exactly the same, but because the two viruses are related and have similar antigens on their surfaces, the antibodies produced against cowpox can also effectively fight smallpox.
(B) Because it is the inoculation of natural, unattenuated virus strains, the efficiency of inducing immunity is indeed better.
(C) The cowpox vaccine was invented by Dr. Jenner in 1796, but smallpox was not eradicated until 1979, declared by WHO, so it took about 183 years.
(D) The risk of variolation comes from the direct inoculation of natural, unattenuated virus strains, not from the route of inoculation. (See B11 Notes vol.1, top of p.6) [From Exam Archaeology Q10]

question: The development of T and B lymphocytes share some common features. Which statement concerning lymphocyte development is correct?

options.A: The anatomic site of rearrangement of antigen receptor genes of both T and B lymphocyte is located in the bone marrow.
options.B: The heavy chain genes of BCR are an evolutionary resemblance to the alpha chain of TCR.
options.C: The selection process for self antigen recognition of both T and B lymphocytes does not occur until it reaches the immature lymphocyte stage.
options.D: There are two checkpoints to ensure the rearrangement of antigen receptor genes of both lymphocytes is successful and non-self-reactive.

explanation:
(A) In the rearrangement of antigen receptor genes stage, both are located in the generative organ (bone marrow/thymus). (B11 vol.1 p.76)
(B) The surrogate light chain of Pre-BCR is evolutionarily similar to the surrogate alpha chain of pre-TCR.
(C) After receiving the self-antigen receptor check, the precursor B cells can develop into immature B cells. The question is a bit roundabout, it doesn't start until the immature stage = it starts before the mature stage.
(D) There are three checkpoints (must-know, if you forgot, please review B11 vol.1 p.77). [From Exam Archaeology Q11]

question: Which statement about B cell development is correct?

options.A: BCR starts to rearrange DH and JH at pro-B stage in two chromosomes.
options.B: BCR rearranges VH to DJH at pre-B, but doesn't express antigen receptor because light chain hasn't arranged.
options.C: Mature B class switch from IgM to IgD.
options.D: After selection, all B that express over affinity to self-antigens are rendered to apoptotic.

explanation:
(A) Correct. (See details in B11 vol.1 p.86)
(B) At the small pre B cell stage, the V-J rearrangement of the light chain has been completed, so it can do the subsequent self-antigen test.
(C) IgM has not disappeared, but there is more IgD expression.
(D) Not all B cells that fail the self-antigen test will undergo apoptosis, they can be rescued through: receptor editing to rearrange genes. (See details in B11 vol.1 p.87, 4 fates of self-reactive B cells). [From Exam Archaeology Q12]

question: During an infection, antigen-presenting cells, such as dendritic cells, pick up antigens at ___, activate adaptive immunity at ___. Then the activated T cells, B cells and antibodies eliminate pathogens at ___?

options.A: the site of infection; secondary lymphoid organs; secondary lymphoid organs
options.B: the site of infection; secondary lymphoid organs; the site of infection
options.C: the site of infection; the site of infection; the site of infection
options.D: secondary lymphoid organs; the site of infection; the site of infection
options.E: secondary lymphoid organs; secondary lymphoid organs; the site of infection

explanation:
After lymphocytes leave the central lymphoid organs, they enter the blood circulation and enter the peripheral lymphoid organs, including lymph nodes, spleen, intestinal lymphoid tissues, and other secondary lymphoid tissues.
Dendritic cells encounter pathogens and antigens at the site of infection, phagocytose them to form antigen-presenting cells, and the peripheral lymphoid tissues (mainly lymph nodes) are where B cells are activated by antigens. B cells and antibodies finally reach the site of infection through blood or lymph circulation and eliminate pathogens. [From Exam Archaeology Q13]

question: Which of the following statement regarding ILCs is not correct?

options.A: ILCs are innate cells and are derived from CLP in bone marrow.
options.B: ILCs don't present T cell receptor or B cell receptor.
options.C: ILCs produce cytokines overlapping with CD4 T cells or CD8 T cell.
options.D: ILC2 produce $\text{IFN-γ}$ to eliminate extracellular bacteria and fungi.
options.E: ILC3 produce IL-17 and IL-22 to recruit and activate neutrophil.

explanation:
(A) ILCs are innate lymphoid cells, like other lymphoid cells, they are produced in the bone marrow (lymphoid lineage) and are distributed in lymph nodes and organs with epidermal tissue.
(B) Neither T cells nor B cells (no TCR, no BCR), no antigen specificity.
(C) ILCs have similar functions to the corresponding T cells (overlapping cytokines).
(D) Type 3 immune response targets extracellular bacteria and fungi, ILC3 can produce IL-17 and IL-22 to attract and activate neutrophils.
(E) Same as (D). [From Exam Archaeology Q14]

question: Which of the following about T cell is NOT correct?

options.A: $\text{T}_\text{H1}$: intracellular pathogen: activate macrophage
options.B: $\text{T}_\text{H2}$: helminth: tissue repair
options.C: $\text{T}_\text{FH}$: extracellular bacteria and fungi: $\text{TNF-α}$
options.D: $\text{T}_\text{reg}$: inhibit T cell function: IL-10 and $\text{TGF-β}$
options.E: Cytotoxic T cell: virus-infected cell: perforin and granzyme

explanation:
(A) $\text{T}_\text{H1}$ mainly fights against bacteria growing in macrophages. $\text{T}_\text{H1}$ cells are activated after recognizing pathogens and secrete cytokine $\text{IFN-γ}$ to transmit signals. After the signal enters the macrophage, it will promote the fusion of lysosomes and phagosomes to form phagolysosomes, activating macrophages to eliminate foreign pathogens.
(B) $\text{T}_\text{H2}$ fights against extracellular parasitic infections (helminth: worms) and secretes IL-4 and IL-13 to activate M2 macrophages and help tissue repair.
(C) $\text{T}_\text{FH}$ is located in B cell follicles and is mainly responsible for helping the maturation of B cells in the germinal center (GC). Extracellular bacteria and fungi are type 3 responses, and the immune effector module includes group 3 ILCs, $\text{T}_\text{H17}$ $\text{CD4}^\text{+}$ T cell, IgG1, IgG2, and neutrophils. $\text{TNF-α}$ is produced by activated macrophages by $\text{T}_\text{H1}$. Neither is dominated by $\text{T}_\text{FH}$.
(D) $\text{T}_\text{reg}$ can secrete inhibitory cytokines (IL-10, $\text{TGF-β}$) to inhibit the immune system.
(E) Cytotoxic T cells can eliminate cells infected by viruses, secrete perforin to make cells perforate, and secrete granzyme to make intracellular substances decompose, thus causing cell apoptosis. [From Exam Archaeology Q15]

question: Which one of the following statements is NOT correct?

options.A: During latency, viruses persist in the host and can be reactivate when the host's immune system is compromised.
options.B: Antibody against one serotype of Streptococcus pneumoniae can protect against another serotype.
options.C: Inherited genetic defect in T cell development can result in defects in other components of the immune system.
options.D: Some intracellular infection like Mycobacterium tuberculosis cannot be completely removed.
options.E: X-linked SCID is an immunodeficiency of IL-2RG, causing problem on IL-2R and affect immune system.

explanation:
(A) Latent infection in the immune response process: pathogens do not show obvious pathological reactions and related pathogen secretions in the individual, but pathological reactions will occur when immunity is low.
(B) The antibodies produced by the immune system are serotype-specific, and the polysaccharides that make up the capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae will form new serotypes as long as they are slightly changed, and cannot be recognized by memory cells infected in the past.
(C) Immune responses can influence each other, so defects in one part of the immune system may also cause abnormalities in other immune functions. T cell deficiency often causes persistent fungal infections, viral infections, or intracellular bacterial infections.
(D) Some intracellular bacteria are phagocytosed by macrophages and can use various methods to prevent the fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes to decompose bacteria. For example, Mycobacterium tuberculosis will treat macrophages as Trojan horses, hiding in them, treating macrophages as UBER, avoiding the immune system, so they can only be temporarily surrounded. If the time is long, they still have a chance to break through the blockade and cause disease recurrence.
(E) X-linked SCID is the most common SCID, which is caused by the mutation of the IL2RG gene, leading to the disappearance of the response of B cells and T cells, resulting in severe acquired immune deficiency, but innate immunity is still retained. [From Exam Archaeology Q16]

question: Which of the following statement is NOT correct?

options.A: Desensitization is the therapy that to restore tolerance to the allergen by reducing its tendency to induce IgE production.
options.B: Delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) is mediated by B cells.
options.C: Anaphylactic shock is caused by IgE secreted by mast cells systematically.
options.D: Celiac disease is a type of hypersensitivity caused by gluten in the food.
options.E: The response caused by antigens in immunology can be either immediate or delayed.

explanation:
(A) Desensitization: exposing to low doses of allergens and gradually increasing the dose, allowing the immune system to slowly tolerate allergens and reduce the induction of IgE production.
(B) Allergies can be divided into 2 types according to the reaction time: immediate type and delayed type (DTH). DTH is regulated by T cells, and allergic reactions appear two or three days after contact with allergens.
(C) In type I hypersensitivity reactions, mast cells are activated to cause histamine and other mediators to spread throughout the body, increasing blood flow and vascular permeability, causing fluid to flow out into the tissue fluid and lowering blood pressure. Mild cases may cause urticaria, and severe cases may cause anaphylactic shock.
(D) Gluten-sensitive enteropathy/celiac disease: ingestion of wheat gluten or similar proteins of other grains induces T cells to attack intestinal cells, causing damage to epithelial cells.
(E) Same as (B). [From Exam Archaeology Q17]

question: All of the following are tenets of the hygiene hypothesis except

options.A: a decrease in allergic disease in developed countries compared to developing countries.
options.B: widespread use of antibiotics interferes with the use and education of the immune system.
options.C: widespread immunization practices compromise the development of a fully functional immune response.
options.D: childhood exposure to microorganisms is reduced.
options.E: antibiotic-driven selection of super bacteria perturbs the immune system.

explanation:
(A) The incidence of allergic reactions in developed countries is higher than that in developing countries.
(B) Correct.
(C) Correct.
(D) Correct.
(E) Correct. [From Exam Archaeology Q18]

question: Allergy and autoimmunity are caused by abnormal immune responses that are against appropriate antigens.
explanation: When the acquired immune system has an inappropriate response to "harmless antigens", it will cause allergies, including allergies and autoimmunity, and allergy cases are usually complex and may combine multiple types of mechanisms. [From Exam Archaeology Q19]

question: Inflammation is harmful so it needs to be avoided in all stages of immunity.
explanation: Inflammation is an important part of the immune response. It helps protect the body from infection and injury, helps clear harmful stimuli, initiates the healing process, and fights pathogens. However, excessive or persistent inflammation can indeed be harmful and lead to various diseases. [From Exam Archaeology Q20]

question: Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction is caused by an IgG-mediated immune response whose main physiological role is to defend against parasite infection.
explanation:
Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction is caused by an IgE-mediated immune response whose main physiological role is to defend against parasite infection.
In tissues, IgE binds to $\text{FcεRI}$ of mast cells and activates them to cause allergies; in the blood, it binds to $\text{FcεRI}$ of basophils. [From Exam Archaeology Q21]

question: Fill in the blanks: fill in antigenic shift and antigenic drift.

options.A: Antigenic Drift
options.B: Antigenic Shift

explanation: If two viruses of RNA undergo gene recombination, it is antigenic shift, which is easy to cause a pandemic; if the gene sequence of RNA virus mutates, it is antigenic drift, which usually only causes a small epidemic. [From Exam Archaeology Q23]

question: Which one is wrong about the mechanisms of T cell immune tolerance?

options.A: central tolerance
options.B: anergy
options.C: presence of regulatory T cell
options.D: receptor editing

explanation:
The body will avoid autoimmune diseases through central tolerance and peripheral tolerance.
Central tolerance: When B cells and T cells develop in the central lymphoid organs, negative selection is used to remove most of the cells that will attack the body, and a few enter the peripheral areas.
Peripheral tolerance: It is carried out after lymphocytes mature and enter the secondary lymphoid organs. For the few lymphocytes that are still autoimmune, methods such as cell anergy, $\text{T}_\text{reg}$ cell regulation (inhibition or differentiation into $\text{T}_\text{reg}$), apoptosis, or the use of immunologically privileged sites to prevent them from contacting self-antigens are used to avoid autoimmunity.[From Exam Archaeology Q24]

question: Regarding the therapeutic targets of solid organ transplantation, which of the following is correct for inhibiting T cell activation?

options.A: cyclosporine and tacrolimus mainly inhibit calcineurin, thereby inhibiting the signal transduction of T cell activation, and further hindering the production of IL-2.
options.B: rapamycin inhibits mTOR molecules, thereby inhibiting T cell activation and proliferation.
options.C: Basiliximab monoclonal antibody directly binds to the IL-2 receptor on the surface of T cells, inhibiting T cell activation.
options.D: All of the above.

explanation: Immunosuppressive drugs: mainly to inhibit T cell activation. [From Exam Archaeology Q25]

question: The factors that trigger autoimmunity include genetic deposition and environmental triggers. When auto-reactive effector cells and regulatory cell imbalance, autoimmune diseases will occur.
explanation:
Two known factors that cause autoimmune diseases.
(1) Genetic specificity: some immune mechanisms are inherently problematic, leading to autoimmune diseases, such as $\text{T}_\text{reg}$ cells are inhibited, making immune suppression dysfunctional; genetic defects related to the regulation of self-tolerance are prone to cause autoimmune diseases, such as knockout of AIRE (reducing the presentation of self-antigens in the thymus, affecting negative selection), Ipr/Ipr gld/gld (belonging to FAS or FAS ligand, related to apoptosis) mutations.
(2) External environmental stimuli: mainly infection, foreign substances can destroy the barriers of cells or tissues, so that some hidden antigens are exposed, destroying self-tolerance, such as pathogens invading, causing originally disabled immune cells to regain activity and attack self-cells.
Regulatory T cells ($\text{T}_\text{reg}$, regulator T cell) will control the T cells in the body that can recognize self-antigens and inhibit their effects to avoid autoimmunity. Therefore, when effector cells and regulatory cell imbalance, autoimmune diseases will occur. [From Exam Archaeology Q26]

question: Immunity signal ligand to inhibit CD8 T cell?

options.A: MHC I
options.B: MHC II
options.C: PD-1
options.D: CD28

explanation: For example, PD-L1 expressed on the surface of tumor cells can bind to PD-1 on T cells, inhibiting the activation of T cells. [From Exam Archaeology Q27]

question: Which is the best description for the rearrangement of T cell receptor alpha chain during the T cell development?

options.A: In the mature T cell.
options.B: After binding to self-antigen.
options.C: Before $\text{CD3}^\text{+}$ T cell.
options.D: In the double negative stage.

explanation:
Beta chain recombination occurs in the double negative DN1 and DN2 stages, and no recombination occurs in the DN3 and DN4 stages.
Alpha chain recombination occurs in the double positive stage.
RAG-1 and RAG-2 recombinase participate in the gene recombination of TCR alpha and beta chains. [From Exam Archaeology Q28]

question: Which of the following is not associated with negative choice?

options.A: Self tolerance
options.B: Thymic medullary epithelial cell
options.C: Recognition of self antigen
options.D: Recognition of foreign antigen

explanation:
If the developing T cell has a high avidity reaction with the self-antigen receptor, it will be eliminated.
Negative selection begins when thymocytes are located in the thymic cortex. It occurs in both the thymic cortex and medulla, but in general, positive selection is done first and then negative selection.
Negative selection is related to a variety of cells that can present antigens, including cortical epithelial cells, medullary epithelial cells, or bone marrow-derived APCs such as medullary dendritic cells and macrophages.
The meaning of Negative choice is to eliminate auto immune. [From Exam Archaeology Q29]

question: Which of the following is not associated with positive choice?

options.A: 決定發育成 CD4 or CD8
options.B: 對自體抗原產生辨識可存活。
options.C: 對自體抗原辨識太過強烈則會發生細胞凋亡。

explanation:
T cells that cannot recognize self MHC antigens will die.
Positive selection occurs in the thymic cortical epithelial cells, mainly by epithelial stroma cells to present MHC antigens for T cell recognition.
Positive selection will also determine the subsequent differentiation of T cells. When the binding degree of T cells to one of the two MHCs is higher, it will induce the production of corresponding transcription factors and determine its co-receptor specificity, that is, transcriptional programming.
The generation of positive selection signals requires the cooperation of TCR and CD4, CD8 co-receptors. The meaning of Positive choice is MHC restriction. [From Exam Archaeology Q30]

question: 下列那個分子在胸腺表現周邊組織的抗原以進行負選擇?

options.A: TdT
options.B: AIRE
options.C: ID2
options.D: IL2

explanation: Autoimmune regulator (AIRE) is expressed in the thymic medulla, inducing the expression of proteins that are generally expressed in peripheral tissues to help negative selection. [From Exam Archaeology Q31]

question: Which of the following is not the antigens recognized by T cells?

options.A: Most T cells recognize peptides and no other molecules.
options.B: T cells recognize conformational determinants of protein antigen.
options.C: $\text{CD4}^\text{+}$ and $\text{CD8}^\text{+}$ T cells preferentially recognize antigens from extracellular environment into vesicles and antigens in cytosol, respectively.
options.D: T cells ...
options.E: T cell receptors recognize only one determinant from antigens.

explanation: T cells recognize linear peptides. Because only linear peptides can bind to the clefts of MHC, and the peptides bound to MHC have already lost the conformation of the protein when they are formed. [From Exam Archaeology Q32]

question: During V(D)J recombination of lymphocytes, recombination signal sequences are recognized by which of the following?

options.A: Receptor tyrosine kinase
options.B: Constant region
options.C: Leading region
options.D: RAG-1 / RAG-2 enzymes

explanation: RAG-1 (Recombination-activating gene - 1) /RAG-2 complex will bind to and cleave the recombination signal sequence (RSS). To perform RAG- dependent V(D)J rearrangement. [From Exam Archaeology Q33]

question: Which one of following features is the characteristic of class II MHC pathway of antigen processing and presentation?

options.A: $\text{β1}$, $\text{β2}$ and $\text{β5}$ subunits of proteasomes are responsible for protein degradation.
options.B: $\text{CD8}^\text{+}$ T cells are responsive T cells.
options.C: Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is the site of peptide loading to MHC.
options.D: Late endosomes and lysosomes are the site of antigen degradation.
options.E: TAP1/2 molecules are involved in peptide transport and loading.

explanation:
(A) is the class I MHC assembly process.
(B) Should be $\text{CD4}^\text{+}$.
(C) It is bound in the lysosome.
(D) Correct.
(E) is the class I MHC assembly process. [From Exam Archaeology Q34]

question: Which of the following statements regarding the sequence of cancer cell editing is correct?

options.A: Escape, Elimination, Equilibrium
options.B: Equilibrium, Elimination, Escape
options.C: Elimination, Equilibrium, Escape
options.D: Elimination, Escape, Equilibrium

explanation:
The evolution of tumors is divided into three stages, and the order is Elimination, Equilibrium, and Escape, so the answer is (C).
The following is a detailed description of these three stages. (1) Elimination: When normal cells become cancerous cells, they express tumor-specific antigens (TSA, tumor-specific antigen), which are recognized and eliminated by the immune system (immune surveillance). (2) Equilibrium: Tumor cells that have not yet been eliminated mutate and grow on the one hand, and fight against the immune system on the other hand, maintaining a certain balance. (3) Escape: As a result of continuous mutations, cells that can escape the recognition of the immune system appear and begin to grow uncontrollably, forming tumors. [From Exam Archaeology Q35]

question: Which of the following is NOT a component of immunological synapse?

options.A: LFA-1
options.B: B7
options.C: MHC
options.D: TLR

explanation: Immunological synapse can be divided into two parts, the core is cSMAC, and the periphery is pSMAC. (1) cSMAC: In addition to TCR complex, CD4 on T cells and MHC on APC, it also distributes other costimulatory molecules, such as CD28 and CD2 on T cells, which can bind to B7.1 (also known as CD80) and B7.2 (also known as CD86) on APC, respectively. LFA-3, these belong to the scope of cSMAC. (2) pSMA: LFA-1 on T cells and ICAM-1 on APC, both of which interact. [From Exam Archaeology Q36]

question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of cold tumor?

options.A: Exclusion of $\text{CD8}^\text{+}$ T cells and NK cells from the tumor.
options.B: Low antigen presentation.
options.C: Immunosuppressive immune cells in tumor (ex. Tregs, MDSC).
options.D: Poor prognosis and response to immunotherapy.
options.E: Elevated effector cytokine, such as Granzyme B.

explanation: (A)(B)(C)(D) are all characteristics of cold tumors, and (E) is a characteristic of hot tumors (See B10 Notes Vol. 4 p.44). [From Exam Archaeology Q37]

question: Which of the following statements regarding T cell-mediated cytotoxicity is correct?

options.A: Cytotoxic T cells induce the senescence of target cells.
options.B: Cytotoxic T cells induce cytotoxic T cell apoptosis.
options.C: Cytotoxic T cells 透過 FAS/FAS-L 的 interaction 使 target cell 死亡。
options.D: Cytotoxic T cells induce shed of membrane-bound vesicle and shrink of target cell.
options.E: Cytotoxic T cells release granzymes and perforin.

explanation: (C)(E) are correct, see B10 Notes Vol. 3 p.26. (B) should be Cytotoxic T cells induce target cell apoptosis. [From Exam Archaeology Q38]

question: $\text{T}_\text{H1}$, $\text{T}_\text{H2}$, $\text{T}_\text{H17}$ 的 signal 3 和 master regulator 對應。
explanation: (See details in B10 Notes vol3. p21) [From Exam Archaeology Q39]

question: How many polypeptide chain(s) is(are) in an IgG antibody?

options.A: one
options.B: two
options.C: three
options.D: four

explanation: Two heavy chains and two light chains form the Y-shaped structure of immunoglobulin, including two arms and one trunk. (Notes vol2 P10) [From Exam Archaeology Q40]

question: Which of the following enzyme can cleave an antibody into two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment?

options.A: Pepsin
options.B: C3 convertase
options.C: Trypsin
options.D: Papain

explanation:
Papain: cleaves at the N-terminus of the disulfide bond between the two heavy chains, producing two Fab and one Fc, and the disulfide bond remains on the Fc.
Pepsin: cleaves at the C-terminus of the disulfide bond between the two heavy chains, producing F(ab') 2 and Fc fragments. (Notes vol2 P12) [From Exam Archaeology Q41]

question: Which one is NOT involved in IgG transfer across the placenta?

options.A: Neonatal of Fc receptor
options.B: Fc Portion of IgG
options.C: MHC class I molecule
options.D: Endosome

explanation: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens to CD8+ T Cells, IgG transport is not related. [From Exam Archaeology Q42]

question: Which statement is not correct?

options.A: Antibody can recognize discontinuous peptide chain, which also called linear epitope.
options.B: Hyper variable region is determined by both V regions of heavy chain and light chain.
options.C: Hyper variable region is also called complementary determining region.
options.D: Antibody usually recognize small part of a large molecule, which can be polysaccharide or proteins.

explanation:
(A) Should be continuous.
Epitopes can be divided into:
1. Conformational epitope: There are multiple antigen determinants, distributed in three-dimensional space. For example: three non-adjacent amino acids on a folded polypeptide can be recognized by antibodies.
2. Linear epitope: The antigen determinant is located in a continuous linear molecular structure. For example: a series of continuous amino acids on a polypeptide can be recognized by antibodies. (Notes vol2 P19)
(B) (Notes vol2 P15)
(C) The loop serves as the complementary determining region (CDRs), which is an important region for recognizing antigens. Six HV loops together determine the binding site of an antigen. (Notes vol2 P15) [From Exam Archaeology Q43]

question: Which one does not involve in the structure -based analysis of antigen-antibody complex?

options.A: monoclonal antibody
options.B: Fc region antibody
options.C: X-ray crystallography
options.D: Epitope

explanation: Epitope is part of an antigen that is recognized by antibodies, and is not used in structure-based analysis of the antigen-antibody complex. [From Exam Archaeology Q44]

question: Which does not happen in the B cell germinal center?

options.A: Somatic hypermutation
options.B: Pre-B rearrangement
options.C: Affinity maturation
options.D: Isotype switch

explanation: (A)(C)(D) events that occur in the germinal center, collectively known as the germinal center reaction, such as somatic hypermutation, class switch recombination, and affinity maturation. (See details in Immunology B11 Notes Vol 2, page 35) [From Exam Archaeology Q45]

question: 下列何者為 TI-1?

options.A: virus HA
options.B: bacterial polysaccharide
options.C: diphtheria toxin
options.D: bacterial lipopolysaccharide

explanation: According to whether the antigen can crosslink with BCR, it is divided into TI-1 and TI-2, TI-1 cannot, TI-2 can. (Examples of TI-1 and TI-2 are detailed in Immunology B11 Notes, page 42) [From Exam Archaeology Q46]

question: Which of the following vaccines administrated in Taiwan is live-attenuated vaccine?

options.A: pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
options.B: human papilloma virus vaccine
options.C: measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine
options.D: seasonal influenza vaccine

explanation:
(A) 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, inactivated vaccine.
(B) Human papillomavirus vaccine, inactivated vaccine.
(C) Measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine, attenuated vaccine. [From Exam Archaeology Q47]

question: Which following about vaccines are not correct?

options.A: There are still infections for which there is no effective vaccines available yet.
options.B: Most vaccines generate antibodies that prevent damages from toxins or that neutralize pathogens and stop infection.
options.C: Polio vaccines usually induce protective T cell rather than antibodies.
options.D: Live-attenuated vaccines are theoretically more potent than killed vaccines.

explanation: Polio vaccine is an inactivated polio vaccine (inactivated polio vaccine), which can produce antibodies against the virus, can prevent polio from invading the central nervous system and prevent paralysis. [From Exam Archaeology Q48]

question: 下列何者不是 FDA approved adjuvant?

options.A: Flagellin
options.B: Alum
options.C: Squalene and water emulsion
options.D: cpg1018

explanation:
(A) Not on the list.
(B) alum is Potassium Aluminum Sulfate, aluminum salt is a common adjuvant, widely used in many vaccines——too many to list. The function of aluminum salt is currently controversial. The more accepted explanation is that aluminum salt can help absorb and gradually release antigens, and recent studies have also pointed out that aluminum salt can stimulate immune cells (including macrophages and dendritic cells) and can regulate immune function.
(C) This type of adjuvant is to enhance the effectiveness of the vaccine by regulating the release effect of the vaccine delivery system. Basically, the vaccine is wrapped in oil so that it can be protected by the oil until it is phagocytosed by phagocytes. This formulation is called MF59, which is to form emulsion droplets through squalene and water, so that it can be effectively phagocytosed by phagocytes.
(D) This type of adjuvant is to enhance immune induction, through the binding of TLR-9 and CpG, inducing phagocytes to engulf the vaccine to enhance the effectiveness of the vaccine. [From Exam Archaeology Q49]

question: 下列何者錯誤?

options.A: Th17 分泌 IL-17, IL-22
options.B: Th2 分泌 $\text{IFN-γ}$ 刺激發炎反應
options.C: 亡佚
options.D: 亡佚

explanation: Th2 is a specialized effector T cell used to fight against parasites and helminths. It will secrete IL-4 and IL-13 to induce eosinophils, basophils, and mast cells. [From Exam Archaeology Q50]

question: Which one of the following does not involve in the production of CAR-T(CART-19)

options.A: retrovirus
options.B: CD16
options.C: 4-1BB
options.D: $\text{CD3ζ}$

explanation:
CAR-T relies on genetic engineering, using Lentivirus (a kind of retrovirus) to make the expression of chimeric antigen receptor——can guide the genetically modified T cells to find cancer cells——and then send it back into the body.
The engineered chimeric antigen receptor includes Costimulatory domain, such as CD28, 4-1BB, and signal domain, such as $\text{CD3ζ}$. [From Exam Archaeology Q51]

question: Which statement is not correct?

options.A: peptide-based vaccine 是一種策略用以辨識 B cell 的 peptide 以促進免疫反應
options.B: live attenuated 可以透過 DNA recombinant 來達成
options.C: conjugated vaccine 的進展有助於流感防治
options.D: 亡佚

explanation:
The correct statement should be that live attenuated vaccines are usually produced through an attenuation process. In this process, the pathogen will be weakened, but it is still alive.
This attenuation can be achieved through various methods, such as serial passage or specific gene mutations.
DNA recombinant technology is usually used to make subunit vaccines or DNA vaccines, not live attenuated vaccines.
(Source: online information, because this information was not found in the notes) [From Exam Archaeology Q52]
